title: obscure
comment:
I do not understand the effect of this. Why is it needed? What does it do?
It probably needs to be removed and whaever problem you had handled differently

LILY: I use this as an import for non-module files. If a file is a module, I use the 'use_module' predicate, if a file is not a module this is how I have been importing its predicates

title: Clarity
comment: 2 remarks:\n-according to the document of asserta/1 https://eclipseclp.org/doc/bips/kernel/dynamic/asserta-1.html the predicate asserted need to be delcared dynamic\n-you really have to document the use of these predicates: what do they represent, what is their format? Best to do that when you delcare them as dynamic

title: Comprehension
comment:
What does this do? Where is it defined? Hard to follow


LILY: This is a challenge I have with Prolog so far, I think we spoke about it at a very early point. I am not sure how to specificy where predicates come from, other than pre-appending the filename/module in the predicate name, though I feel this becomes messy quite quickly. (Eg: statement_handler__function_handler(...)

title: Comprehension
comment: Where is this used?\n\nLILY: It is not used in code. I use this predicate in the TkEclipse GUI during development

title: Comprehension
comment: What does this do? \n\nLILY: Imports the test_case_generation functions. It is used as the last line of the function_handler predicate

title: rename
comment: So why not rename statement_handler to handle and get rid of this special case?\n

title: rename
comment: Why this extra level of direction? Just handle the declartions here rather than in a seperate file\n\nLILY: There currently is declaration predicates in declarations.pl,and this utilises those. The predicates could be moved into this file, though it I prefer it in a seperate file due to the statement_handler curating which predicates require to be called rather than doing it here (With exceptions if they are minimal in size. A declaration can be of many types, leading me to seperation them).

title: understanding
comment: why do you create a copy of the varaible just to get the name?\n\nLILY: Without the copy, the var_names predicate (Coming from .names file from the parser) will ground the variable by matching it to an atom, blocking it from being assigned a c_var at a later point
Yes, I do not understnd why this would be needed.\n

title: issue
comment:
As mentionned,
all the integer varaibles that need labeling need to be sent at the time in one go to the solver and not one by one.

This is for optimisation purposes wuithin the solver. This is important for efficiency purposes.
